name: Pittsburgh, PA
tagline: Steel City reinvented—affordable, walkable, authentic neighborhoods with real seasons

diversity.summary: SERIOUS POLICE ISSUES: Data shows Black people in Pittsburgh are **disproportionately arrested and over-policed**—particularly for gun possession charges. Pittsburgh Foundation report: "Police here killed and maimed Black men again and again" over the past 25 years. Pennsylvania State Police have documented racial profiling issues. **But outside of police, Pittsburgh is a working-class city with a significant Black population (~23%) and doesn't have the same overt racism as rural PA.** It's a Rust Belt city with typical segregation and police problems—not welcoming, not hostile, just...American urban reality. Candace would face police risk but not social ostracism.
diversity.diversity_index: ~66% White, 23% Black, 6% Asian, 3% Hispanic (old-school Rust Belt demographics)
diversity.notable: Documented police violence against Black residents; racial profiling in traffic stops; over-policing; but ~23% Black population means not isolated

safety.summary: Pittsburgh is generally safe, especially in popular neighborhoods. Some areas (Hill District, Homewood) have higher crime, but most residential areas feel very safe. Overall crime rates are moderate. The city's small-town feel within neighborhoods contributes to safety.

scenery.summary: Three rivers (Allegheny, Monongahela, Ohio) converge dramatically downtown. Hilly terrain with bridges everywhere creates unique topography. Mount Washington overlook is iconic. Fall foliage is spectacular. Not mountains but distinctive, beautiful in its own industrial-meets-nature way.

climate.summary: Four true seasons with cold, snowy winters—42 inches of snow is real winter, not mild. Hot, humid summers. Beautiful spring and stunning fall colors. Cloudy/gray days are common (only 160 sunny days). This is proper Northeast weather. Not ideal for warm-weather preference.

culture.summary: Pittsburgh has transformed from steel town to tech/healthcare hub with retained authenticity. Excellent museums (Carnegie, Warhol), thriving food scene (Primanti Bros, ethnic neighborhoods), craft beer, indie music. Strong neighborhood pride, sports culture (Steelers, Penguins), and working-class roots. Feels real, not manufactured—gritty but cultured.

pros: Very affordable—best value for money on this list
Walkable, characterful neighborhoods with strong identities
Four real seasons with beautiful fall colors
Good food scene and craft beer culture
cons: LEAST diverse option on this list—segregation is real
Interracial couple experience may be mixed (neighborhood dependent)
Gray, cloudy weather (160 sunny days vs Denver's 300)
Smaller city feel—may lack energy after 1-2 years
Job market smaller than Denver/Charlotte (though growing)
saturday: You wake up in Lawrenceville to gray skies (it's Pittsburgh) and walk to Commonplace Coffee for espresso and pastries. The morning is spent browsing vintage shops and record stores on Butler Street, then you cross the Allegheny River to the Strip District for the massive Saturday market—pierogies, fresh produce, ethnic groceries stacked high. Lunch at Christos Mediterranean Grille downtown brings Greek comfort, then you ride the incline up Mount Washington for the iconic Pittsburgh skyline view—three rivers converging, bridges everywhere. Dinner is at Cure in Lawrenceville (charcuterie, natural wine), then drinks at a neighborhood dive. Pittsburgh feels real, gritty, authentic—no pretense, just people living their lives.

food_scene.summary: Pittsburgh's food scene has transformed from blue-collar diners to a legitimate culinary destination. The city retains its ethnic neighborhood roots (Polish, Italian, Jewish) while adding modern chef-driven concepts. It's affordable, authentic, and punches above its weight.
mediterranean_options: Nicky's Thai Kitchen (also serves Mediterranean fusion)
food_scene.food_culture: Pittsburgh food culture is rooted in its immigrant history—Polish pierogies, Italian hoagies, Jewish delis (Primanti Bros. sandwiches with fries and coleslaw ON the sandwich). The city has evolved with farm-to-table spots (Legume, Cure), craft breweries, and ethnic neighborhoods (Squirrel Hill's kosher food, Polish Hill). It's affordable, hearty, and real.
food_scene.grocery_quality: Whole Foods, Trader Joe's, Giant Eagle (local chain), ethnic markets in Squirrel Hill and Strip District. Solid grocery access with strong international options.

neighborhoods.name: Lawrenceville
neighborhoods.vibe: Pittsburgh's hipster heart—artsy, indie shops, young professionals
neighborhoods.diversity_notes: Most diverse neighborhood, younger crowd, more accepting
neighborhoods.why_for_them: Trendy, walkable, arts scene. Best bet for diversity/acceptance in Pittsburgh. Restaurants, breweries, galleries.

neighborhoods.name: Shadyside
neighborhoods.vibe: Upscale, tree-lined, cafes and boutiques—Pittsburgh's polished neighborhood
neighborhoods.why_for_them: Walkable, safe, beautiful. Great shops and restaurants. Less diverse but quality of life is excellent.

neighborhoods.name: Squirrel Hill
neighborhoods.diversity_notes: Religiously diverse, welcoming, strong community bonds
neighborhoods.why_for_them: Walkable, safe, excellent food (Middle Eastern, kosher, eclectic). Community feel. One of Pittsburgh's most accepting areas.

neighborhoods.name: South Side
neighborhoods.vibe: Nightlife and restaurants along East Carson Street—active, mixed vibe
neighborhoods.why_for_them: Walkable, lots of activity, affordable. Can be loud/party-focused. Great restaurant row but may feel college-y.

neighborhoods.name: Point Breeze
neighborhoods.vibe: Residential, tree-lined, near Frick Park—quiet urban neighborhood
neighborhoods.why_for_them: Safe, green, near park. More residential/family-oriented. Walkable but quieter. Good for settling in vs exploring.
